repnme.cdata!:
South Sudan - Support to Agriculture and
            Forestry Development Project (ERL)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Support to Agriculture
            and Forestry Development Project (ERL) for South Sudan were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Grantee performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            during implementation, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)
            should mainly play a supportive role to the Local
            Governments (LGs) to enable LGs to take responsibility for
            development programs in their jurisdiction. Future
            development programs should aim at having a working system
            and resource allocation that raise the status of the LGs and
            their staff. Development programs in fragile environments
            should ensure that some expertize and capacity remains in
            program areas to continue assisting beneficiary communities.
            Government commitment that assures the continued employment
            of the trained and experienced extension staff is necessary.
            Project design should refrain from ex-ante selection of
            institutions to provide exclusive services or inputs, and to
            become sole implementers of parts of a project in a
            situation where the authorities are uncertain about the
            idea. Even in rapid response programs, project design should
            endeavor to define and specify in detail all tasks to be
            accomplished. Implementing agencies should prepare exit
            plans under different closing-date scenarios, to minimize
            the inefficient use of resources and avoid inconclusive tasks.

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Support to Agriculture and Forestry
            Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Support
            to Agriculture and Forestry Development Project is to
            increase the productivity and production of participating
            smallholder farmers in agriculture and forestry. This paper
            seeks to extend the closing date for project from June 30,
            2012 until December 31, 2012 to allow completion of ongoing
            civil works contracts which have been delayed by the slow
            movement of construction materials to sites-a result of
            rains that have worsened the already poor road conditions.
            The paper is also a revision to targets for some indicators
            in light of recent availability of more reliable data. The
            closing date was once again extended to June 30, 2012 when
            additional financing of US$14 million, mainly to support the
            construction of a number agricultural research and seed
            system facilities, was approved for the project.

            and Forestry Development Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Support to Agriculture and Forestry
            Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Support to
            Agriculture and Forestry Development Project (SAFDP) for
            Sudan is to increase agricultural productivity of
            smallholder households by facilitating the adoption of
            improved technologies and strengthening capacities of the
            Government of Southern Sudan (GoSS), State and Local
            Governments as well as private sector to plan and respond to
            identified needs in agriculture and forestry. The changes
            are twofold: (i) the revision to the project development
            objective (PDO) to make it consistent with of the PDO of the
            additional financing approved in March 2011 and (ii) the
            extension of the closing date of both the original grant and
            additional financing from October 31, 2011 to June 30, 2012.
            At approval of the additional financing it was clear that
            the completion of the expanded scope of activities will
            necessitate an extension of the project closing date to June
            30, 2012.  However, since the closing date of the parent
            Multi Donors Trust Funds- Southern Sudan, or MDTF-SS was set
            at December 30, 2011 and the process to extend it was still
            underway, the extension of the closing date of SAFDP to June
            2012 could not be granted. The extension of the closing date
            of the parent trust fund to December 31, 2012 has been
            completed and it is possible now to extend closing dates of
            both the original SAFDP and the Additional Financing, or AF
            to June 30, 2012.
